q: What was the original name of Bahadur Shah I?
desc: Bahadur Shah I's original name was Muazzam. He was also titled Shah Alam I.

q: Who ascended the throne with the help of Zulfikar Khan?
desc: Jahandar Shah became emperor in 1712 with the support of Zulfikar Khan.

q: Which Mughal emperor abolished the Jizya tax?
desc: Jahandar Shah abolished the Jizya tax during his short reign.

q: Which emperor's reign saw the emergence of the Sayyid Brothers?
desc: The Sayyid Brothers rose to prominence during the reign of Farrukhsiyar (1713–1719).

q: Who was ruling when Nadir Shah invaded India?
desc: Nadir Shah invaded India during the reign of Muhammad Shah and took the Peacock Throne and Kohinoor diamond.

q: Who marched towards Delhi during Ahmed Shah's reign?
desc: Ahmed Shah Abdali, a general of Nadir Shah, marched to Delhi during Ahmed Shah’s reign.

q: Which emperor saw Delhi occupied by Ahmed Shah?
desc: During Alamgir II's reign, Ahmed Shah Abdali occupied Delhi.

q: Who couldn't enter Delhi for 12 years during his reign?
desc: Shah Alam II was kept away from Delhi for 12 years due to political instability.

q: Which Mughal emperor gave the title 'Raja' to Ram Mohan Roy?
desc: Akbar II gave the title 'Raja' to social reformer Raja Ram Mohan Roy.

q: Who was the last Mughal emperor?
desc: Bahadur Shah II was the last Mughal emperor and played a symbolic role in the 1857 Revolt.

q: Who authored Tuzuk-i-Babari?
desc: Tuzuk-i-Babari is the autobiography of Babur, the founder of the Mughal Empire.

q: Which Mughal emperor wrote Tuzuk-i-Jahangir?
desc: Jahangir documented his reign in the memoir Tuzuk-i-Jahangir.

q: Who wrote the Akbarnamah and Ain-i-Akbari?
desc: Abul Fazal authored the Akbarnamah and Ain-i-Akbari, chronicling Akbar’s reign.

q: Which author wrote Padshahnama?
desc: Hamid Lahori authored the Padshahnama, a chronicle of Shah Jahan's reign.

q: Majma-ul-Bahrain was written by?
desc: Darashikoh wrote Majma-ul-Bahrain, a book promoting the unity of Hindu and Islamic philosophies.

q: Who authored Alamgirnama?
desc: Mirza Muhammad Qasim wrote the Alamgirnama, chronicling Aurangzeb’s rule.

q: Who succeeded Bahadur Shah I?
desc: Jahandar Shah succeeded Bahadur Shah I in 1712.

q: Which Mughal ruler was considered a pensioner of the East India Company?
desc: Akbar II was a nominal ruler and a pensioner under the East India Company.

q: Who ruled from 1719 to 1748?
desc: Muhammad Shah reigned from 1719 to 1748, during which Nadir Shah invaded India.

q: Under whose reign did Ahmed Shah Abdali invade India?
desc: Ahmed Shah Abdali invaded India during the reign of Ahmed Shah (1748–1754).

q: Who took away the Kohinoor diamond from India?
desc: Nadir Shah took the Kohinoor diamond and the Peacock Throne during his invasion of India.

q: Who was made the symbolic leader during the 1857 Revolt?
desc: Bahadur Shah II was declared the symbolic leader of the 1857 Revolt against the British.

q: Which Mughal ruler’s autobiography is Tuzuk-i-Babari?
desc: Tuzuk-i-Babari is the autobiography of Babur, detailing his conquests and administration.

q: Who ruled the Mughal Empire the longest among the Later Mughals?
desc: Shah Alam II ruled from 1759 to 1806, the longest among the Later Mughal emperors.

q: What was the reign period of Bahadur Shah I?
desc: Bahadur Shah I ruled the Mughal Empire from 1707 to 1712.

q: Who documented Shah Jahan's reign in Padshahnama?
desc: Padshahnama, a detailed account of Shah Jahan's reign, was written by Hamid Lahori.

q: Alamgir ruled during which years?
desc: Alamgir II ruled the Mughal Empire from 1754 to 1759.

q: Who was the Mughal emperor during the loss of Punjab and Multan?
desc: During Ahmed Shah’s reign, Punjab and Multan were ceded to Ahmed Shah Abdali.

q: Which ruler's court was known for cultural revival despite decline?
desc: Muhammad Shah's court saw a cultural revival even though the empire was weakening.

q: Where was Shivaji born?
desc: Shivaji was born at Shivner to Shahji Bhonsle and Jijabai.

q: Who was Shivaji's religious teacher?
desc: Samarth Ramdas was the religious teacher of Shivaji.

q: Who was Shivaji's guardian?
desc: Dadaji Kondadev was Shivaji’s guardian.

q: In which year was the Treaty of Purandar signed?
desc: The Treaty of Purandar was signed between Shivaji and the Mughals in 1665.

q: Where was Shivaji coronated?
desc: Shivaji was coronated at Raigarh in 1674.

q: What title did Shivaji assume at his coronation?
desc: Shivaji assumed the title of Haindava Dharmadharak (Protector of Hinduism).

q: Which post was responsible for military affairs in Ashtapradhan?
desc: Sar-i-Naubat was the military chief in the Ashtapradhan council.

q: Who looked after justice in Shivaji's council?
desc: Nyayadhish was responsible for justice in Shivaji's Ashtapradhan.

q: Who handled intelligence in Shivaji's Ashtapradhan?
desc: Waqenavis handled intelligence in Shivaji’s administration.

q: Which successor of Shivaji fought the Battle of Khed?
desc: Shahu, a successor of Shivaji, fought the Battle of Khed in 1708.

q: Who was the first Peshwa?
desc: Balaji Vishwanath was the first Peshwa of the Maratha Empire.

q: Which emperor recognized Shahu as king of Swarajya?
desc: Farukh Siyyar recognized Shahu as king under the agreement by Balaji Vishwanath.

q: Who is considered the greatest exponent of guerilla tactics after Shivaji?
desc: Baji Rao is regarded as the greatest exponent of guerilla tactics after Shivaji.

q: Which Maratha leader defeated the Siddis of Janjira?
desc: Baji Rao defeated the Siddis of Janjira during his military campaigns.

q: Who conquered Bassein and Salsette from the Portuguese?
desc: Baji Rao conquered Bassein and Salsette from the Portuguese.

q: What was Balaji Baji Rao popularly known as?
desc: Balaji Baji Rao was popularly known as Nana Sahib.

q: When was the Third Battle of Panipat fought?
desc: The Third Battle of Panipat was fought in 1761 between the Marathas and Ahmed Shah Abdali.

q: Who fought the Third Battle of Panipat against the Marathas?
desc: Ahmed Shah Abdali defeated the Marathas in the Third Battle of Panipat.

q: Who helped in administration under Shivaji?
desc: Ashtapradhan was a council of eight ministers aiding Shivaji in administration.

q: Who was the accounts minister in Shivaji’s council?
desc: Mazumdar or Amatya was in charge of accounts in the Ashtapradhan council.

q: What does 'Haindava Dharmadharak' mean?
desc: ‘Haindava Dharmadharak’ means ‘Protector of Hinduism,’ a title assumed by Shivaji.

q: When was Shivaji coronated?
desc: Shivaji was coronated in 1674 at Raigarh.

q: Who succeeded Shivaji immediately after his death?
desc: Sambhaji succeeded Shivaji immediately after his death.

q: Who was the father of Shivaji?
desc: Shahji Bhonsle was the father of Shivaji.

q: Who was Shivaji's mother?
desc: Jijabai was Shivaji's mother.

q: What system began under Baji Rao?
desc: The system of confederacy began under Baji Rao.

q: Which Peshwa is called the ‘kingmaker’?
desc: The Sayyid Brothers were considered ‘kingmakers’ during the Maratha period.

q: What is the period of Maratha empire?
desc: The Maratha Empire lasted from 1674 to 1818.

q: Who was known as Nana Sahib?
desc: Balaji Baji Rao, son of Baji Rao, was known as Nana Sahib.

q: Who founded the Sikh religion?
desc: Guru Nanak Ji (1469–1539) was the founder of Sikhism and the first of the ten Sikh Gurus.

q: Which Guru invented the Gurmukhi script?
desc: Guru Angad (1539–1552) invented the Gurmukhi script which later became the standard writing system for the Punjabi language.

q: Which Guru struggled against the sati and purdah systems?
desc: Guru Amardas (1552–1574) actively worked against the practices of sati and purdah and established 22 preaching centers (Gadiyans).

q: Who founded the city of Amritsar in 1577?
desc: Guru Ramdas (1574–1581) founded Amritsar in 1577 on land granted by Mughal Emperor Akbar.

q: Who composed the Adi Granth?
desc: Guru Arjan Dev (1581–1606) composed the Adi Granth, which was later expanded into the Guru Granth Sahib.

q: Which Guru established the Akal Takht?
desc: Guru Hargobind Singh (1606–1644) established the Akal Takht and fortified Amritsar, introducing the concept of Miri-Piri (spiritual and temporal authority).

q: Who provided care to Dara Shikoh?
desc: Guru Har Rai (1644–1661) is known for providing medical and moral support to Dara Shikoh, the brother of Mughal emperor Aurangzeb.

q: Who was the youngest Guru in terms of age at the time of Guruship?
desc: Guru Harkishan (1661–1664) was the youngest of all Sikh Gurus and became Guru at a very young age.

q: Who was the ninth Sikh Guru?
desc: Guru Tegh Bahadur (1664–1675) was the ninth Guru of Sikhism and is remembered for his sacrifice to protect religious freedom.

q: Who founded the Khalsa?
desc: Guru Gobind Singh (1675–1708) founded the Khalsa in 1699, creating a distinct Sikh identity and martial community.

q: Which Guru's period marks the end of human Guruship in Sikhism?
desc: Guru Gobind Singh declared the Guru Granth Sahib as the eternal Guru before his death in 1708, ending the line of human Gurus.

q: Who was granted land by Akbar to found Amritsar?
desc: Akbar granted land to Guru Ramdas, who used it to found the city of Amritsar in 1577.

q: Who composed the original version of the Guru Granth Sahib?
desc: Guru Arjan Dev compiled the Adi Granth, which was later finalized into the Guru Granth Sahib by Guru Gobind Singh.

q: Which Guru established 22 preaching centers (Gadiyans)?
desc: Guru Amardas created 22 preaching centers to spread Sikh teachings more effectively.

q: Which Guru fortified Amritsar for protection?
desc: Guru Hargobind Singh fortified Amritsar and introduced the concept of armed defense for Sikhs.
